rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effect of the war on Canadian foreign trade
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Canadian history from the beginning can almost be written in terms of her foreign trade. It was not only the inquisitive interest in discovery, the lust for adventure, and the sudden patriotic fervour that sent the little wooden ships across the Atlantic to Canada, from France and later from England, to poke tentatively around the Maritime coast and sail up the St. Lawrence; it was trade. In the same way that the famous East India and French East India Companies with their strong mercantile backing opened India and the treasures of the East to Europe, so French businessmen (such as DeChastes, Delients, and LaSalle) and the Hudson’s Bay and North West Trading Companies were responsible for the opening and early development of Canada. At every step we find a trading interest responsible for Canadian growth. Indeed, on many an occasion, such as the dispute between Frontenac and Bishop Laval over the liquor trade with the Indians, and Governor Murray’s trouble with the merchants, the domestic interest of the colony came into conflict with the trading interest, controlled from abroad; and the latter usually won out. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: World War, 1939-1945 -- Economic aspects -- Canada
Canada -- Commerce

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The mechanics of intervertebral joint failure
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Backache is one of the scourges of mankind. Indeed, it appears to be the painful part of the price exacted from Homo Sapiens for the priviledge of being upright if not always being upstanding. Other upstanding vertebrates also pay for this priviledge, and so the kangaroo and chimpanzee fall heir to the inevitable, suffering the disablement of over-worked discs.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Experimental studies on myocardial protection
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The protective role of prior myocardial damage against subsequent necrotizing action of isoproterenol was studied in laboratory rats. Myocardial damage was usually induced by coronary artery ligature. Significant protection was achieved by ligature of either the left or right coronary artery one week prior to the isoproterenol injection (P <0.01 for the left ventricle). Previous isoproterenol administration also provided significant grade of protection (P <0.05) in the one group tested. Necrosis of another organ in the body (kidney infarct) afforded no protection. Adrenal regeneration hypertension markedly increased the animals’ sensitivity to isoproterenol. In a subsequent study, the time relationship of protection produced by ventricular infarct was followed. It was found that protection appears as early as 24 hours after coronary artery ligature, but recedes later in the course of healing, there being almost no signs of a protective effect after one month. In the third experiment, the possible role of endogenous catecholamines in protection was sought in animals treated with reserpine, iproniazid (Marsilid R) and by a combination of both. No significant differences from the control group were found.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pathology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Foetal distress equals foetal acidosis
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Our main concern as obstetricians has always been to decrease material and perinatal mortality. Foetal distress is an obscure term requiring further research towards establishment of a precise definition. The progress in physiology and pathophysiology favours a biochemical definition of foetal distress as being a metabolic or respiratory acidosis. Acidosis in the foetus may be determined by scalp sampling and measurement of blood gases. By routine use of this technique in obstetrical units, it is hoped that the stillbirth rate will be decreased, the apgar score at birth will.be increased, and mental retardation with or without neurological deficit will also be decreased. Other areas of research will blossom from the availability of the foetus for study, such as the physiology of the foetal pancreas.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Investigative Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Experimental studies of factors affecting survival of autogenous joint transplants
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Comparison in dogs between free whole joint transplants and those in which the blood supply was preserved showed a distinct difference. In most of the free transplants, the articular cartilage ultimately was completely destroyed, whereas in those with a preserved blood supply normal structure was retained. S35incorporation studies in free whole joint transplants in rabbits demonstrated normal uptake in the grafted articular cartilage up to four to five weeks. Beyond twelve weeks, there was marked decrease to eventual complete absence of uptake. Free hemi-joint transplants in dogs showed a somewhat slower pattern of deterioration but similar to that of the whole joint transplants. Analysis of the above results suggests that post transplantation ischemia is the principle factor in the ultimate articular degeneration and that this is mediated through its effect on the subchondral circulation. In addition altered mechanics seem to play an important secondary role.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Surgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Gastrointestinal hormone and amino acid induced insulin release from isolated pancreatic islets of Langerhans
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Ingestion of glucose and amino acids is associated with a greater rise in serum insulin than is intravenous infusion. Evidence indicates gastrointestinal hormones mediate the response. Mostly on the basis of in vivo studies, it is thought that secretin and enteric glucagon mediate the effect during glucose absorption and pancreozymin and pancreatic glucagon probably are involved during amino acid absorption. Gastrin may produce secretin release and act indirectly. The present studies were performed using isolated islets of Langerhans of the rat obtained according to the method of Lacy and Kostianovsky. Secret in and glucagon have been demonstrated to produce insulin release at both 50 and 300 mg% glucose. Gastrin was without effect. Pancreozymin produced insulin release at 300 but not 50 mg% glucose. Arginine produced insulin release at both 50 and 300 mg% glucose but leucine was without significant effect. The significance of these findings in relation to in vivo findings is discussed and the need for further work is stressed.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Human growth hormone and d2-macroglobulin
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: By radioimmunoelectrophoresis and chromatography on Sephadex G-200, we have confirmed the existence of an "in vitro" binding of HGH by human α2-M. We have demonstrated that bound HGH is immunoreacti ve; but that its reactive sites are partially blocked by the binding protein at least when HGH concentration is in the physiologic range. Indeed, the precipitation of α2-M by a specific G-globulin resulted in the appearance of a greater quantity of HGH in the supernatants than in the initial sera. Furthermore, by incubating fluorescein-tagged HGH with normal, acromegalic and hypopituitary sera, we demonstrated with chromatographic studies on Sephadex G-200 an inverse relationship between the endogenous HGH plasma concentration and the percentage of binding of FITC-tagged HGH to α2-M "in vitro". We have also shown the existence of an influence of HGH on the metabolism of α2-M allowing us to propose a role for α2-M in the growth promoting effect of HGH. The variations of α2-M levels observed after administration of HGH to 3 normal subjects and 8 hypopituitary patients, could represent the overall result of an equilibrium between synthesis of α2-M and its utilization as a "building block" of connective tissue, both synthesis and peripheral utilization being influenced by HGH.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Investigative Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Purification of an antihistamine-like principle(s) of the Hungarian oak gall and its efficacy compared to tomatine and gomatine
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The purpose of this work was to purify and, it possible, to isolate an antihistamine-like principle(s) from the Hungarian oak gall. Although the study fell short of isolating the active principle(s), it succeeded in obtaining a highly purified tannin-tree fraction by silica gel G and sephadex LH-20 column chromatography. According to the thin layer chromatography, the active tractions so obtained still contain at least 4 - 8 substances. The antihistamine-like activity of the purified oak gall extract was compared to that of tomatine and gomatine in the guinea pigs. All three substances significantly inhibited histamine-induced bronchoconstriction. Tomatine and gomatine significantly reduced the effects of both histamine and bradykinin but the purified oak gall extract only antagonized the histaminic affects. Gomatine and the purified oak gall extract but not tomatine exerted anti-anaphylactic activity. None of the three substances inhibited the PCA reaction.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Renewal of paneth cells
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The radioactive tracer 3H-thymidine was used to investigate the origin and fate of Paneth cells in mouse duodenum, jejunum and ileum. Three different techniques were used to accomplish labeling: 1. single injection, 2. a 4-day administration in drinking water and 3.continuous infusion up to 10 days. One-µ thick, Epon-embedded, single or seriaI sections were stained with Regaud's iron-hematoxylin, radioautographed and counterstained with safranin O. Paneth cells were shown to be a distinct cell type independent of columnar or goblet cells. They did not divide but arose by transformation of a precursor cell which is believed to be the intercalated columnar cell. The Paneth cell population was a slowly renewing one with a turnover rate of 14-16 days. The population consisted mostly of mature cells which differed from young newly-formed ones in their granular and nuclear characteristics. The maturation process consisted of gradual changes in the granules and nucleus.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Urinary excretion of cortisol and corticosterone metabolites by the newborn infant
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Cortisol, cortisone, their respective ester sulfates, tetrahydrocortisol, tetrahydrocortisone and their respective glucuronides were quantified by double isotope assays in 24-hour urine specimens obtained on the 2nd and 6th days of life from both male and female infants. On the 2nd day of life the sum of the mean urinary excretion of cortisol sulfate (60 µg/day) and cortisone sulfate (29 µg/day) represented 64% of that of tetrahydrocortisone glucuronide (138 µg/day). All other metabolites of cortisol with the exception of cortisone were excreted at a rate lower than 8 µg/day. Of 5 metabolites of corticosterone (corticosterone, 11-dehydrocorticosterone, their respective ester sulfates and tetrahydrocorticosterone glucuronide) the excretion of corticosterone sulfate (mean: 60 µg/day) was the greatest.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Investigative Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An electron microscopic study of the interacellular colloid droplets in the rat thyroid gland
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: An electron microscopic study of colloid droplets and dense bodies in the thyroid follicular cells of TSH-injected and non-TSH-injected rats indicated the following: 1) Colloid droplets and dense granules were situated on the average slightly nearer to the apex of the cell than to the base. On the average, one micron separated a colloid droplet from the nearest dense body. TSH did not significantly affect these values. 2) Colloid droplets varied in density between gray and white. The lighter droplets showed matrix filaments of a size similar to reported dimensions of thyroglobulin crystals. Density variation may represent stages of thyroglobulin digestion. 3) The relative infrequency and non-specificity of close association of dense bodies with colloid droplets, and the absence of electron density changes in colloid near dense bodies, suggest there is possibly only a minor contribution by dense bodies of enzymes for colloid droplet degradation.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Oxidative addition of silicon hydrides to hydridocarbonyltris (triphenylphosphine) iridium (I)
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The oxidative addition reaction of several silicon hydrides to hydridocarbonyltris (triphenylphosphine) iridium (I) was studied. Stable products were obtained in the cases of trichlorosilane, triphenylsilane, triethoxysilane, methyldichlorosilane and phenyldimethylsilane. Trimethylsilane also reacted but the product formed was unstable in the absence of excess trimethylsilane.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Interaction between background activity and evoked potentials
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The evolution of summation technique as applied to human evoked cerebral potentials is reviewed. Attention is directed to the interaction between evoked potentials and background cerebral 'noise'. The influence of various forms of noise are studied. Excitability cycles are analyzed and distortions of the response to the second stimulus caused by the response to the first are indicated. Care should be taken in interpretation of changes in potentials evoked during periods of different background activity as they may be due to the changes in the background rather than in the signal. Summation and subtraction of alternate responses gives a clear estimate of the background activity present during evoked responses. The effects of the stimulus and response on the background activity are described.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Neurology and Neurosurgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effort of phenelzine on the metabolism of ethanol
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Studies were conducted to determine the effect of phenelzine on the pharmacology and metabolism of ethanol. Pretreatment for one half hour with phenelzine (40 mg./kg. i.p.) prolonged the mean ethanol sleeping time in mice by more than 350%, but, unexpectedly, decreased the toxicity of ethanol, as reflected in a change of LD 50 from a control value of 4.14g./kg. to 5.16 g./kg. A partial explanation of these results was thought to reside in the effect of phenelzine on the rate of ethanol degradation. Determinations of ethanol concentrations in whole mice over a 4 hour period indicated that phenelzine caused a 43% increase in the time required to eliminate one half the amount of ethanol initially injected. Acetaldehyde concentrations after ethanol were found to be lower in phenelzine pretreated mice. In vitro, phenelzine inhibited the oxidative activity of yeast alcohol dehydrogenase by a competitive interaction with both DPN+ and ethanol at enzymic receptor sites. In contrast, the inhibition of liver alcohol dehydrogenase by phenelzine was competitive with + DPN only, and non-competitive with respect to ethanol.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pharmacology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Adjuvant experimental polyarthritis
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Among the several methods used for the reproduction of an experimental arthritis in various species and strains of laboratory animals, the one induced by the injection of Freund adjuvant in rats seems to be the most attractive. Although no experimental arthritis satisfactorily resembles human rheumatoid arthritis, adjuvant polyarthritis appears to be highly promising because of its systemic manifestations, the clinical course, the migratory polyarthritis, the serological alterations, the roentgenologic changes and the histology. The disease is reproduced by a single subcutaneous injection of the rat’s tail with 0.8 mg. of dead mycobacterium butyricum suspended in 0.1 ml. paraffin oil.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Surgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Histamine release by cortisone induced hyperglycemis
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The purpose of this work was to determine in guinea-pigs whether or not a single injection of cortisone caused a detectable change in plasma histamine level, and whether or not this effect was a direct action of cortisone on histamine metabolism. A single dose of cortisone caused a significant increase in plasma histamine level. Cortisone also increased the level of blood glucose. When cortisone induced hyperglycemia was abolished by the injection of insulin, no rise in the level of plasma histamine occurred. The increase in plasma histamine level following a single cortisone injection could be duplicated by the administration of glucose. These results suggest that the increase in plasma histamine concentration induced by cortisone was mediated by the hyperglycemic effect of cortisone. The chronic administration of cortisone or glucose over a period of 10 days showed that both substances decreased tissue histamine. Histamine depletion by cortisone was greater than that caused by glucose and could be partially blocked by daily injections of insulin.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pharmacology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The placental aromatization of 159-hydroxysteroids
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Labelled and non-labelled 15α-hydroxysteroids were prepared by the microbiological hydroxylation of appropriate steroid precursors. When 14C-I5α-hydroxyandrostenedione was incubated with a fortified human placental 10,000xg supernatant fraction, the major metabolite was 15α-hydroxyestradiol, while smaller amounts of 15α-hydroxytestosterone and 15α-hydroxyandrostenedione were also detected. When the human placenta was perfused in situ with the same substrate, 15α-hydroxyestradiol was isolated from the placenta and perfusate while 15α-hydroxyestrone and 15α-hydroxyandrostenedione were found only in the perfusate. In view of the presence of neutral and phenolic 15α-hydroxysteroids in late pregnancy urine, it can be concluded that 15α-hydroxyestrogens are partly derived from neutral 15α-hydroxysteroids by placental aromatization. Furthermore, in the perfusion studies the distribution of metabolites isolated from the placenta and perfusate indicates that 15α-hydroxyestradiol is bound to placental tissue.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Gastric denervation and secretion
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This thesis presents an experimental investigation into the effects of gastric denervation on gastric secretion. It is presented in two sections and Section l is sub-divided into two parts. The first part of Section I deals with the effect of unilateral vagotomy in the rat. Unilateral vagotomy reduced the spontaneous secretion of gastric juice in the pylorus-ligated rat. The mean acid output after unilateral vagotomy was significantly smaller than the acid output in control rats, and significantly greater than the mean acid output after bilateral vagotomy. Similar differences were observed whether unilateral vagotomy was performed in the abdomen at the time of pyloric ligation, or in the neck one week prior to pyloric ligation. Part two of Section l is concerned with the effect of unilateral vagotomy on dogs with a gastric fistula, following sham-feeding and gastrin infusions. Difference between pre- and post-unilateral vagotomy results only became apparent at the upper levels of stimulation. Explanations have been advanced for the results but the gross reduction may represent the sum of a number of different effects. It is suggested that only ‘maximal stimuli’ may be useful experimentally and clinically for differentiating varying degrees of partial denervation of the stomach. In Section II the effect of immunosympathectomy on gastric secretion is considered in the rat. The immunologically suppressed sympathetic nervous system gives rise to an increased incidence of gastric glandular ulceration in pylorus ligated rats. This is accompanied by a decreased mucus content in the gastric juice with no appreciable change in acid or pepsin output. Adrenaline treatment of these animals seems to reverse the ulcerogenic effects of sympathetic ablation and restores mucus production to normal and above normal levels.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Surgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Study of electric potential on the human renal pelvis and the ureter
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The function of the renal pelvis and ureter was studied in both Paraplegics and non-Paraplegic patients, by recording the electrical potential and pressure simultaneously, by using a modified double platinum electrode cardiac catheter, and a skin electrode of silver-silver chloride with saline diffusion barrier. An outline has been given to the previous methods of studies, It is concluded that: There is pelvic perestalsis. The frequency of contraction of the renal pelvis is greater than that of its corresponding ureter .The average intrapelvic contraction pressure is lower than ureter. The amplitude of contraction wave is higher in the upper and middle third of the ureter than in the lower third. The pelvic "Pacemaker" exists. The ureteric contraction wave in lower third is higher in Paraplegics than in non-Paraplegics. The electrical impulse in the pelvis and ureter precedes the contraction wave. The actual electrical impulse giving rise to the contraction wave in the ureter is preceded by several smaller impulses. Recommendation has been made for improvement of material and technique for future experiments.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Surgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effort of shock on body fluid distribution
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Recent reports have stressed the importance of maintaining the extracellular water (ECW) volume in the patient in shock by administering large volumes of balanced salt solution. The present study was undertaken to determine whether a significant decrease in the extracellular water volume occurs in experimental hemorrhagic shock or in a series of patients with septic shock. Multiple isotope dilution techniques were employed for simultaneous measurement of the total body water (TBW), ECW and plasma volume. In addition, red cell mass vas measured in many of the human studies. In hemorrhagic shock multiple tracers of varying function and molecular size were used. Deficits observed were not statistically significant and could be accounted for byvascular compartment loss due to the withdrawal of blood samples. In 11 patients in septic shock the observation of an increased ECW and increased total exchangeable Sodium not associated with an increase in TBW has been recorded. In addition, no correlation was found between this observation and the more usually performed tests of hemodynamic and metabolic functions in the shock patient. These studies do not support the concept of selective extracellular fluid deficits in hemorrhagic shock or septic shock. Unwarranted infusion of large amounts of salt-containing solutions should be avoided unless further scientific support for their use can be obtained.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Surgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The in situ metabolism of progesterone in the human feto-placental unit
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In the study of the in situ metabolism of progesterone- 4-14C in the midterm human fetoplacental unit, the labeled hormone was injected into the umbilical vein at the time of hysterotomy and the circulation was left intact for 15 minutes. After delivery, the placenta, umbilical cord, and ten fetal tissues from two male fetus, gestational age 21 weeks, were selected for the isolation of labeled metabolites. A total of eight unconjugated metabolites of progesterone were isolated and identified. The reduced metabolites were 20α-dihydroprogesterone, pregnanolone, 3β-hydroxy-pregnan-20-one and pregnanediol; the hydroxylated metabolites identified were 6β-hydroxyprogesterone, 16α-hydroxyprogesterone, 17α-hydroxyprogesterone and hydrocortisone. These results demonstrated that the human fetus at midterm pregnancy can actively transfom progesterone reaching it from the placenta into a number of reduced and hydroxylated metabolites and that the fetal adrenal and the liver were the most active sites of this metabolism.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Metabolism of progesterone in the feto-placental unit of the rhesus monkey (Macaca mulatta)
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Progesterone-4-14C was injected into the umbilical vein of the Rhesus monkey with the fetus in utero. The umbilical circulation was left intact for 10 minutes after which time a number of fetal tissues and the placenta were analyzed for labeled metabolites of progesterone. Eight metabolites were identified and these are: allopregnanedione from placenta, pregnanolone from liver and intestine, 3β-hydroxy-sα-pregnan-20-one from testes, lung and placenta, 3α-hydroxy-5α-pregnan-20-one and pregnanediol from liver, 20α-dihydroprogestarone from intestine and lung, 17α-hydroxyprogesterone from adrenal and testes, and androstenedione from adrenal. From this data it was concluded that progesterone is mainly metabolized to reduced products by the placenta and fetal tissues of pregnant Rhesus monkey. In contrast to the human fetus, conjugation of metabolites with sulfuric or glucuronic acid does not occur to any extent in fetal tissues of the Rhesus monkey.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Moment-resistant connections in precast concrete
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Tests are performed on two commercially available column-to-base connection arrangements. The structural characteristics of both systems are presented in the form of moment-rotation curves. A method by which these connections can be used in a practical design problem is proposed. One type of moment-resistant beam-to-column connection for precast concrete is developed and tested in the laboratory. The structural characteristics of three different sizes of prototypes using the same arrangement are presented in the form of moment-rotation curves. The applicability to design of these connections is outlined through a brief theoretical study.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Civil Engineering and Applied Mechanics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Correlation between gastric secretory capacity and duodenal histology in patients with ulcer-like syndrome
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Patients who complained of ulcer-like symptoms without radiological evidence of peptic ulcer were studied. Their maximum histamine stimulation tests and perorally obtained duodenal cap biopsies were compared to those of patients suffering from proven duodenal ulcer, functional dyspepsia and to those of a group of normal controls. Patients with typical duodenal ulcer symptoms without radiological evidence of ulcer had normal maximum histamine tests but their duodenal biopsies showed inflammatory changes comparable to those of patients with proven duodenal ulcers. The ulcer group had, in addition, elevated maximum histamine test results. Normal controls and patients with “functional dyspepsia" had normal maximum histamine tests and normal biopsies. These studies add support to the concept of a definite clinical physiopathological entity, "chronic duodenitis", characterised by ulcer-like symptoms without radiologicaly demonstrable change in the duodenum, increased inflammatory cell infiltration of the lamina propria, and normal acid secretion.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Investigative Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Storage of canine kidneys: biochemical evaluation of protein and RNA synthesis of stored kidneys
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Biochemical parameters were developed to study survival of renal tissue stored under ischemic conditions. Canine kidneys were perfused with extracellular fluids containing different buffers at 37.5°C, 2°C and at temperatures below 2°C, using dimethyl sulfoxide. Biopsies of renal cortex were taken after varying storage times and were used to study 1) protein synthesis, using C14-leucine incorporation, 2) ribonucleic acid synthesis, using C14-uridine incorporation. It was shown that protein and nucleic acid synthesis are closely related to the whole organ survival and indeed, a reliable index of kidney viability could be estimated from these parameters.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine
